title: 113_s832
content: The Act titled "Improving the Lives of Children with Spina Bifida Act of 2013" establishes a pilot program to provide case management services to children of Vietnam veterans and certain Korea service veterans born with Spina Bifida, as well as children of women Vietnam veterans born with certain birth defects. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a pilot program to provide case management services to covered individuals in rural areas who do not have access to such services at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The program will run for three years. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a pilot program in rural areas for three years, providing integrated services to covered individuals lacking access to comprehensive case management services. Locations will be selected based on rural criteria. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a pilot program in rural areas for three years, providing integrated services to covered individuals. This includes coordination of health care, monetary, and general care services, transportation services, and other services deemed appropriate. The Secretary will inform covered individuals of available services, contract with third parties for case management, and determine enrollment criteria. Preliminary reports will be submitted. The Secretary will submit preliminary reports to Congress on the implementation and operation of the pilot program, including the number of covered individuals enrolled. The Secretary will submit a final report to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs within 180 days after the pilot program's completion. The report will include details on the number of covered individuals receiving benefits, cost-benefit analysis, utilization of case management, findings, conclusions, and recommendations for the program's continuation or expansion. The Secretary will submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing the findings, conclusions, and recommendations for the pilot program. Funding for the program will be derived from existing appropriations for care and case management under title 38, United States Code. The pilot program aims to provide assisted living to children of Vietnam veterans and certain Korea service veterans born with spina bifida and children of women Vietnam veterans born with certain birth defects. Funding for the program will come from existing appropriations for care and case management under title 38, United States Code. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a pilot program to assess providing assisted living, group home care, or similar services instead of nursing home care to covered individuals entitled to benefits under chapter 18 of title 38, United States Code. The pilot program will last for three years initially, with the possibility of a two-year extension. The pilot program, conducted by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, will provide covered individuals with integrated services such as assisted living, group home care, and transportation services. The program will last for five years and aims to inform all covered individuals of the available services. The pilot program, led by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, will offer integrated services like assisted living and group home care to covered individuals. The Secretary will also collaborate with service providers and determine enrollment criteria. Reports on the program's progress will be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The report on the pilot program will include details on implementation, number of individuals receiving benefits, cost comparisons between different types of care, analysis of costs and benefits, and findings and conclusions. The Secretary will submit a final report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding the pilot program, including findings, conclusions, and recommendations for continuation or expansion. The Secretary will submit recommendations for the continuation or expansion of the pilot program, with funding derived from existing sources for nursing home care under title 38, United States Code.
